messages.message: Hi all, I really want everyone to start thinking about Data privileges a bit more. I just created a quick video to show how easy it is to expose data on the entire web based on our notions of Public vs Private. Can someone please champion this problem:
@Aaron Vontell, qq, in this case (refer video) what will happen if the attacker clicks create project in SDLC menu (top right)? will it create a project?

I think you’re actually talking about two different things here?
1. Can we improve our messaging around public repos?
2. Do we want to support a fully public repo?

I think before we do anything about #2, we need to understand the current use cases? and why they were supported in the first place.

I believe the use case was originally intended to supported our schools/profs in a teaching environment, so that they could allow all their students (regardless of whether or not they had instabase accounts) to have read-only access to the class material.
Yes the origination was different but now that we are building out a much different vision we need to re-think a lot of our security but naming conventions as well.
Side-question, why do you need to switch environments between instabase and dogfood? The reason the view is different is because the cache in each env is different btw.
It’s a poorly learned behavior from demo’ing back in the day. I could just stick with one environment but just used to flipping between them.

Re this overall discussion, yeah I wonder what model we should take, for instance public/private folders on Google Drive are different from public and private repos on GitHub, no idea which is better, maybe we ask customers what they think

It really doesn’t matter what customers think because no one is using Instabase SaaS, they are all behind a massive firewall. My bet though is, if any one of them used Instabase SaaS they would want more of a safeguard that an employee could switch between public and private and all their data instantly gets exposed

Salesforce who is all SaaS, imagine if an employee at General Electric could hit the public button and now all of Sales Force GE (in that particular workspace/repo) was accessible by the outside world….
I’d guess that GE would instantly say it can’t be that easy to expose data.

The other thought here is, we are thinking of giving site admins more oversight into what’s inside user-owned repos (at least from a management persepctive). So I can imagine site admins being able to audit all repos and at least be aware of which repos are actually public.
I just think there needs to be AT LEAST one more layer before WORLD public and Instabase public
Wait why do we even have world public
@Justin for university classes that use Instabase I believe
Dump thoughts in here for tracking? https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/INFRA-825
Also remember the argument isn’t should we have Private or Public. The argument is what guardrails and precautions should we bake into the product to stop accidental misconfigurations/dataloss.
yup that’s fair, there’sa definitely a bunch of things we could improve there. I’ll add a few more ideas to the jira.
